title: Feeling Heard in Conflict
description: Explore whether you feel listened to during disagreements

questions.text: Even when we disagree, I feel my partner is really listening.

therapeutic.rationale: Feeling heard during disagreement is often more important than agreeing. When partners truly listen—even while disagreeing—conflicts become conversations rather than battles.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel heard, explore what listening looks like for them. Eye contact? Reflecting back? Not interrupting? The other may be listening but not showing it.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual feeling of being heard during conflict creates productive disagreements.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps you feel heard when you're disagreeing with your partner?

questions.text: I sense my partner trying to understand my point before responding.

therapeutic.rationale: Understanding before responding shows respect and curiosity. When partners respond before understanding, conversations become two monologues rather than dialogue.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel understood first, explore what happens instead. Interruption? Quick rebuttals? Slowing down to understand is a learnable skill.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual commitment to understanding first creates meaningful exchange during conflict.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Does your partner try to understand you before responding? How can you tell?

questions.text: I don't have to repeat myself multiple times to be heard.

therapeutic.rationale: Needing to repeat yourself signals you don't feel received. When partners absorb what's said the first time, speakers feel valued and heard.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner repeats themselves often, explore what's happening. Is the message unclear? Is the listener distracted or defensive? Both sides contribute to the pattern.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual feeling of being heard the first time creates efficient, respectful communication.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How often do you find yourself repeating the same point? What do you think is happening?

questions.text: I feel understood when I explain my perspective during disagreements.

therapeutic.rationale: Accurate reflection proves listening happened. When your partner can mirror your point—even while disagreeing with it—you know they've genuinely taken it in.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner can't reflect accurately, it may be about listening skills or about the speaker's clarity. Both can work on their side of the exchange.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual ability to reflect each other accurately creates foundation for resolving differences.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Can your partner accurately summarize your point during disagreements?

questions.text: I feel my perspective matters to my partner, even in conflict.

therapeutic.rationale: Feeling that your perspective matters—that it's considered, not dismissed—sustains engagement in difficult conversations. Dismissal leads to withdrawal or escalation.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel their perspective matters, explore what communicates dismissal. Tone? Speed of response? Lack of acknowledgment?
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual sense that both perspectives matter creates collaborative conflict.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes you feel your perspective matters—or doesn't—during conflict?
